article.headline: Another ho-hum victory
article.linkText: Sooners off to best start since 1999-2000
article.story: NORMAN, Okla. (AP) -- The Oklahoma Sooners look like one of the nation's best teams. Even Kelvin Sampson had to acknowledge that. Freshman Drew Lavender had 13 points and seven assists to lead No. 11 Oklahoma to a methodical 83-56 win over winless Prairie View A&M on Saturday night. The Sooners (7-0) had what amounted to a breather after pulling out consecutive last-second wins over top-20 opponents Michigan State and Purdue. Those victories have convinced the usually finicky Sampson that his young team is playing as well as any in the country right now. "I think we're as good as a lot of teams," Sampson said. "I watched Kentucky and Michigan St. -- we're as good as them. "We have a chance to be pretty good. I don't think we're by any means a finished product." De'Angelo Alexander added 11 points for Oklahoma. Reserves Jaison Williams and Johnnie Gilbert had 10 apiece. The Sooners are off to their best start since the 1999-2000 season, when they began 9-0. No one could have expected this much early success in what was supposed to be a rebuilding year. The Sooners had to replace three key seniors -- All-America Hollis Price, Quannas White and Ebi Ere -- who guided the team to three straight Big 12 tournament titles and a game within its second straight Final Four. But Sampson has somehow managed to get promising results from the youngest team in his 10 seasons in Norman -- the starting lineup has two freshmen and two sophomores. "We're gaining confidence as a team after a couple of big wins," said Oklahoma center Jabahri Brown, the only senior to start. "Overall, we're coming along really well. We're putting the parts together and everyone is chipping in and doing their part to help the team." Prairie View (0-5) mostly let fly with off-balance jumpers and runners, clearly resigned to not being able to match the Sooners basket for basket. The Panthers shot only 32 percent, including 17 percent from 3-point range. Only three Prairie View players -- Tyrone Nelson, Roderick Riley and Kevin Cooper -- scored in the first half. No one else scored for the Panthers until Dashon Harper's basket nearly eight minutes into the second half. It also was the team's first field goal after halftime, cutting Oklahoma's lead to 60-32. "I thought we were a little bit lackadaisical and sluggish (in the first half)," Sampson said. "I was pleased with the way we come out in the second half." Nelson, who this summer was granted a release from his letter-of-intent to attend troubled Baylor, had eight points and 16 rebounds for Prairie View. Cooper scored 16 and Riley added 14. The Panthers committed 22 turnovers -- right at the Big 12-leading average of Oklahoma's opponents this season. "Last year's OU team was great but his year's team has their own flavor," said Prairie View A&M coach Jerome Francis Jr., whose team lost 75-63 in Norman last year. "They look for the hot hand and ride it." The loudest cheers from the mostly disinterested crowd of about 5,000 came late in the second half when the public announcer revealed that OU quarterback Jason White had won the Heisman Trophy. One of the more comical sights in the game was when 5-foot-7 Lavender found himself guarding Riley, Prairie View's lumbering 6-11, 307-pound center, late in the first half. Lavender tumbled to the ground, trying to draw a charge, as Riley scored over him. Oklahoma forward Kevin Bookout, the team's leading rebounder, sat out the game to rest his right shoulder. He is recovering from offseason surgery.
